segments.text: While you were in Washington with the Oceanographic Office, how large did it become?
I left there in 1952 to go to Hawaii, and I honestly can't answer that, because the Division of Oceanography began very small, five people, as I mentioned.
But it was only one small portion of the then Hydrographic Office.
There was air navigation.
There was the chart construction group, the print shops for navigation charts for both the sea and aviation.
And the Division of Oceanography was a very small group.
And it grew.
And by the time we left, I left, I'm sorry,
About all I can remember, it must have been 200.
Now, that may be large.
I'm not sure.
It was while I was in Hawaii that the decision was made to change the name from the Navy Hydrographic Office to the Navy Oceanographic Office.
Interesting thing about that group under Dr. Fleming is that a large percentage of your
Government oceanographers in the United States came from there.
Bob Abel, who was the head of the Sea Grant program here with NOAA.
Murray Schaefer, oceanographer of the Bureau of Ordnance.
Bill Littlewood, who became the science attache in Copenhagen and then Tokyo and is now with AID in the Middle East.
Sidney Upham, who went with the Navy Oceanographic Instrumentation Office.
You can just go right down the list.

And I would say 80% of the people that were with the Navy Oceanographic Office who came out of school with a degree in some of the natural sciences, but no degrees in oceanography, have ended up in quite responsible positions
positions in oceanography and academia and in the government.
Would you suggest that this is why?
Because you guys were the first people?
Yeah, sure.
Okay.
I can't think of any other reason, really, because there were three places in the nation at that time that, quote,
turned out oceanographers, end quote.
That was Scripps.
No, actually only two.
Scripps and the University of Washington in terms of formal academic training.

The University of Washington only after Dick Fleming left the Navy Oceanographic Office, then the Hydrographic Office, and became the director of the Division of Oceanography at the University of Washington.
Woods Hole did not turn out anybody in oceanography because it was a research institution.
with interactions with MIT, it now is a degree-granting organization.
But that's what I've lost touch, perhaps, in the last 10 years.
So for all those years, there simply was no place.
You didn't have the big Institute of Marine Sciences in Miami.
In fact, I used to go to Dr. Smith's lab out on
Coral Island at the edge of Miami where he was looking at the rate of fouling on panels as a function of anti-fouling paints.
He brought that lab from himself up to a multi-million dollar institution and it is now.
You didn't have Texas A&M oceanographically speaking.
You didn't have Oregon State.
When you decided to go to Hawaii, why?

Well, I don't want to go into the dramatic experience of pulling, but I had accepted the job to go there because I pretty well knew the people and the work in Western Europe, from Scandinavian countries to, say, Spain.
So I wanted to go to Hawaii so I could see the work being done in the Orient.
Also, because the man at that time, the director of the lab in Hawaii, was Oscar Elton Asete, who I looked at as one of the greatest of the marine ecologists in terms of the fishes.
In fact, his whole thesis was that you could go from the wind
to the water, to the fish.
And if you learned enough about the meteorological events controlling the water, you could go directly from the wind to the fish, he used to say, and put the oceanographers out of work.
And the deputy director at that time was one, Donald McKernan, who went to Alaska from our lab in Hawaii and then became the director of the Bureau of Commercial Fishers.
To go to a place like that where I was within 500 yards of the lab from my home, I lived in faculty housing, had two strong sons.
I just seemed ideal because of the wheelchair and because I hadn't quite learned how to live in society yet after over a year.
So Hawaii had everything.
challenging research in the oceanography, descriptive oceanography of the tropical Pacific.

I could bring my background in biology to bear in that I was to be in charge of an oceanographic program that was concerned with why the tuna fish lived where they lived and did what they did, and to work with superb people in a tropical paradise.
My God, what more could a man ask for?
You keep speaking of descriptive oceanography.
And it seems that's what you were primarily involved in, in terms of descriptive oceanography.
But I noticed from your vita that you did some of the primary work, for example, in bringing a computer into oceanography, which helps to change the nature of oceanography.
Do you have any explanation for that?
Oh, I guess it was just being where I was at the time that I got interested in that.
Descriptive oceanography is really passe.
At the time, I liked to think of myself as a descriptive oceanographer along with probably one of the best, Joe Reed, Val Worthington at Woods Hole, Gary Metcalf at Woods Hole.
These were people who went to sea to describe how the ocean looked.

The fact that you had a current flowing across the tropical that became the Gulf Stream, that became the North Atlantic current, that then returned back into this, and here's this, as here goes the sea.
That's describing what the Gulf Stream looked like.
So we made hundreds of sections across the Gulf Stream to see what the cold wall looked like and so forth.
Most of that was done with damn crude instruments.
We simply didn't have sophisticated electronic instruments.
And if we did, none of us knew how to operate the damn thing anyway.
Then I went with the beer commercial fisheries in Hawaii, came back to Washington, and then went to Miami.

I began to realize that the data we were collecting, we had two big ships in Miami, the Geronimo and the Undaunted, two big ATAs that we converted for oceanographic and fishery research in the Gulf of Guinea.
And we were becoming swamped by the data.
We weren't able to keep up with the volume of the data.
We now had underway instruments, for instance, that we hadn't had before.
And then we had one of the first of the salinity temperature depth recorders in lieu of a Nansen bottle cast and reversing thermometers.
You lowered this damn monster into the ocean, and on deck you got a record of temperature salinity against the depth.
So while we were in Miami, the University of Miami, which is also on Virginia Key,
installed a computer.
And one of the leaders in its use was a man by the name of Dr. Bill Richardson, who you may recall drowned in the Gulf of Maine last year out on an oceanographic cruise.
And so he convinced me that if I would support them with a few dollars that we could develop computer programming that would allow us to begin
processing these data and make them more amenable to auto manipulation.
And then I got an offer and went down there in 65 and 67 as the director of the National Oceanographic Data Center here in Washington.
So I came back to Washington again, where I always seem to come no matter where the hell I go, took over NODC and immediately
was able to convince the advisory board to provide us with the resources to install a big, in those days, a big IBM 36040.
And from there on, we have just gotten bigger and bigger and bigger.
And right now, we have six centers in EDS.
We have one primarily concerned with oceanographic data, one primarily concerned with atmospheric
buried the data, and there we have records that go back to the early 1800s.
And then one concerned with earthquakes, sunspots, marine geology, angio-physics, and so forth.
So there's no way, for instance, at NCC in Asheville, we have 126 million sheets of weather observations, which if we did not have those keypunches available on
computer technology.
There would be no way we could, well, this last winter, which was so atypical, because of what we had there, we were able to go back and see.
You learn from the atypical, really, not from the typical.
1917 and 18 were so much like this year that it was unbelievable.
Now, Jerome Nomias, a man at Scripps, feels that the anomalies of temperature in the North Pacific
control the weather patterns.
And for what it's worth, in August of 1917 and in August 1976, sea surface temperatures in the North Pacific were five degrees below the 100-year norms.
And the jet stream, the high altitude air flow, changed both times to move the warm
northern Pacific air masses up to Alaska, and then swoop down into the eastern United States and freeze the hell out of it.
And in both years, 1918 and 1977, the departures from the mean temperatures in the southeastern United States ran as much as 15 degrees.
1932 is the warmest year in 100 years of records.
and the sea surface temperatures in the North Pacific the previous August were well above the normals available.
So, what that means, I'm not sure.
It could be purely coincidence, but it sure is suggestive that Jerome Neimias is right.
Now, when you first arrived at Florida, exactly what was your job there?
Well, you mean...
I'm sorry, I'm Hawaii.
I want to drop back from Florida to Hawaii.
I was the chief of the oceanography branch.
I came there after a gentleman by the name of Thompson Cromwell, about whom you may have heard.
He was killed in an airplane crash in Mexico and was one of the most promising of the younger oceanographers.
And he's the one who discovered equatorial undercurrent
now called the Cromwell Current in the Pacific.
And he wanted to go back to Scripps, so there was an opening at Hawaii.
And as I say, I was in Europe when the offer came, and I took it.
And then I had a year out until I went back, and they very kindly held the job open for that whole year.
And what sort of...
innovations or changes did you try to make after you arrived at Hawaii?
What sort of things did you want your lab to do?
Two things, actually.
The first thing I speak of because I remember it so vividly.
The lab opened in 1949.
I went there in 1952.
By that time, there were about ten cruises between Hawaii and
the Marquesas Islands, areas south of the equator.
And through a variety of circumstances, none of the data had ever been worked up.
So my first job was to prepare all of these data, quality control, tabulate, and publish.
So the first three years, I guess, I spent
with a group of very fine people.
We introduced ADP techniques in terms of key punching and that type of equipment.
We didn't have a computer, but we had the ADP equipment.
Then we began looking at the data as it described the oceans.
The tropical Pacific circulation is fascinating because it's such a wide ocean compared to the Atlantic with the bulge of Africa and the bulge of South America.
You have a beautiful east-west, 4,000 miles to work in.
And the tunas were distributed pretty damn well from the Baja California to Hawaii across the Pacific.
to the Asiatic waters of the Japanese.
And north of Hawaii was the so-called transition zone between the warm subtropical and the cold dilution waters where the albacore lived.
So we had the skipjack tuna, the albacore tuna, and the elephant tuna.
And then there was a big skipjack fishery in Hawaii.
These fisheries change.
One year it's good, and the fishermen catch a lot of fish, and the next year it's lousy.
How come the difference?
Do they have a different migration path?
Were the eggs and a larvae of that year class impacted by a bad year in terms of the temperatures and length of the year?
For instance, the albacore moved from the Oregon fishery across the whole North Pacific in one season and entered the Japanese longline fishery.
They moved across the transition zone, we found out ultimately, because that's where the soury, a little fish that the albacore eat, lives.
Most all animals have a zone.
of conditions, let's just say temperature, salinity, oxygen, you can think of other things, that's optimum.
So the maximum number of the animals are in this zone and then you get fewer and fewer and fewer and fewer.

Okay, if this is where the food of the albacore live and I'm an albacore here and I want to get here, I'm going to move right through there the whole damn way across because that's where I can find food.
You find fish where they can make a living.
So we were in an area that was unexplored.
The tropical Pacific was essentially unknown in a descriptive oceanography sense.
Equatorial undercurrent, equatorial countercurrent, the upwelling.
How long after the upwelling, the cool,
deep waters come to the surface loaded with nutrients.
So you begin to get development of phytoplankton, zooplankton, the forage organisms, and concentrations of the tunas.
We didn't know.
It was an exciting time for a person with my kind of a background, because it was all new.
And calculus, forget it.
I wouldn't have gotten through calculus in graduate school
My wife had them in a math major.
So descriptive oceanography, you have to have kind of an innate curiosity.
Why does A follow B, and why does B follow C, and what happens if A doesn't happen in terms of B and C?
Okay, you go out and you plan a series of observations, and you watch these things change, and you say, ha-ha.
But you don't sit down and use integral and differential calculus, which is a beautiful way now to do things, because you have massive computers into which you can feed models of the ocean.
And then you can ask the computer, if I change A, what will happen to B?
Or if I reverse A, what happens to B and C?
have now gone from the descriptive to the analytical, I think, in the marine sciences.
You're now beginning to ask, what is the sequence of events and how fast do they happen?
How much warm water is carried in the Gulf Stream from the tropical Atlantic into the temperate?
What's the impact of the climate?
What would happen if the Gulf Stream would slow down or speed up?
These things, now you can...
Well, the Von Arxes and the Stommels and the Smagorinskys and others can begin looking at these in the big computers.
How long were you in Hawaii?
Ten years, almost to the day.
And while there, did you seem to feel as if after ten years your work there had completed?
Yeah, there was a combination of a lot of circumstances actually.

After ten years hearing each of us give the same papers over again, only in a slightly modified form, I felt somewhat isolated from the marine oceanographic, which is a redundancy, the marine community of scientists, because it was not easy for me to travel.
That was the personal aspect of it.
1961, my son was old enough, we took off.
We went to England and we spent six weeks in Europe.
And from that time on, I have gone to oceanographic meetings and delegations
was the chairman of one of the major committees of the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission ever since.
I've gone to Europe at least two times a year ever since.
You were in Helsinki though in 1960, were you not?
Yeah.
Didn't you go to work in the International Conference there?
Is that when your son went with you?
Yes, yes, yes.
I said 61.
I'm wrong.
Oh, okay.
I guess it was 19... Well, I may be wrong.
No, it was either 60 or 61.
He and I took off and went to the International Union for Geodesy and Geophysics in Helsinki.
Then we went to every major oceanographic lab between Helsinki and Lisbon.
Now, is this the first time you've become seriously interested in international cooperation among oceanographers?
I think so.
I was interested prior to that.
I was in Europe when I was exposed to polio.
So I had been with the IUGG, but I guess that's when I first realized I wanted to do more than I was doing.
We went to Copenhagen.

to the organizational meeting of the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission, at which time I had a chance to interact with George Deacon and Roger Revelle and Secretary Wakelin and people that I had heard about but hadn't had an opportunity to really interact with.
Warren Wooster, Dr. Bernica from Hamburg,
all of these people.
I became really excited, began going as a member, as an observer to the delegations, then as a member.
Then when I became, I became involved in the planning of a 14-nation oceanographic survey of the tropical Atlantic called ICITA.
And we got together the ships from each of the nations, our own included, and had a midwinter and a midsummer survey from Africa to South America on and to the Gulf and Caribbean.
And other than in the ocean, that was the first major cooperative international oceanographic survey.
And I made so many friends.
just became so thoroughly captivated with the idea of working with these people.
For instance, in West Africa, Sierra Leone, Republic of Ivory Coast, Congo-Brazzaville, a nation.
My first experience of the problems between the black people and the Portuguese, and I began to realize that international oceanography
I can remember we were in Abidjan in the Republic of Ivory Coast, and in our hotel was a bowling alley.
And my son and I went down, and here was two people from East Germany, and two people from Kiel in West Germany, three people from the USSR,
Mario from Portugal, several nations, all around a big table, eating hot dogs and hamburgers.
And they had an eggs and larvae bowling team and the adult fish bowling team.
And on the way back to the hotel, my son said, Dad, you know.
If oceanographers could run the governments of the world, there would be no problems.
You've never seen such a mixture of people as far as their political beliefs, at least in terms of the national postures we're concerned.
East Germany, West Germany, USSR, Portugal, the black Africans, United States, Canada.
We just had a ball there.
In fact, they
I think perhaps we got more oceanography done as a result of that.
Do you think that international cooperation was even possible before 57 and the IGY?
Tom?
Sure.
I think through the International Union for Geology and Geophysics and the International Council of Scientific Unions,
a group called YAPSO, the International Association for Physical Oceanographers.
Yeah, sure.
It was somewhat of a different type of cooperation, though.
It was people gathering to hear each other give learned papers and be totally bored, of course, but this compared to bringing together other ships of lots of nations
exchanging the scientists on ships, exchanging equipment, the data management problems.
It was this type of international cooperation that was the result of the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission.
You see, there's the international aspects, like ICSU, International Council for Scientific Unions.
That's international.
The Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission, the World Meteorological Organization, the Food and Agricultural Organization are technical bodies of the United Nations and are intergovernmental.
When you go to one of those meetings as a member of the delegation, you speak for your nation and commit resources for your nation.
When you go to an international meeting, you don't.
You are gathering as a group of scientists to exchange ideas.
So there's a big difference there.
And you were active, really, in terms of international cooperation, and I assume still are from 1960 on.
Did it seem to you that international cooperation blossomed and grew in this period?
Well, it changed.

A little difficult to explain when or how, but if we go back to 1953, 1963, the International Cooperative Investigations of the Tropical Atlantic, that was the first of a series of intergovernmental oceanographic commission-coordinated activities.
The intergovernmental...
investigations of the Kirishio, the IIOE, the Intergovernmental Investigations of the Indian Ocean, the

The CCAR, the IOC-coordinated cooperative investigations of the Caribbean and adjacent regions, that was in the descriptive oceanography phase when nations brought their resources together because no one nation could look at the whole tropical Atlantic at once.
We don't do that anymore because we don't really need that anymore.
I'm not saying we know enough about the oceans.
I am saying that you no longer can generally bring together ships and scientists from six, eight, ten nations into these types of operations.
We don't have the need or the resources.
We're now beginning to look at the regional problems, and we're beginning to bring scientists together to look at things like a mole.
